719462f-a.text:
East Houston Street, south side, west from (No. 47) but not including Mott, to Lafayette Streets, showing prominently the Puck Building (from Mulberry to Lafayette Streets). It is a handsome edifice in the Italian Renaissance style, and is occupied by the J. Ottman Lithographing Co., the foremost establishment of its kind on the American continent, and the magasine'Puck, a publication satirising the political and social life of our country. The building was erected sometime between the second and third quarters of the 19th
century and is 9-stories tall.
June 3, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A detail of the Puck Building (the S.W. corner of East Houston and Mulberry Streets) at an earlier date, showing the pretty, emblematic figure of Puck, standing on a long, graceful column, with a crayon as a staff in one hand and a mirror in the other.
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
719462f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Mott Street, Manhattan, NY

719461f-b.folder: Houston Street (East) & Mott Street, Manhattan, NY

719465f-b.text:
(1)
64 East Houston Street, north side, between Mott and Elizabeth Streets, showing the entrance to a 1-story frame house, situated at the rear of No. 66 (part of which is seen on the extreme right), and is occupied by a smithy. The block of of houses of which these are a part were later razed to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway).
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view from the same point of vantage at a later date and after demolition. The three 6-story tenements shown on the right are Nos. 291 to 295 Elizabeth Street. The cleared area is a playground today (1937).
March 12, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

721774f-a.text:
Mott Street, west side, north from Houston, to, but not including Bleecker Streets, as seen through clearance on Houston Street, for the
Eighth Ave., Subway.
September 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
721774f-a.folder: Mott Street & Houston Street, Manhattan, NY
